Yes, but Bitcoin maintains consensus with decentralised mining, rather than a list of ~10 trusted computers.
In Bitcoin if the seed nodes are down, all existing nodes keep working, and new installs can manually seed.
A (properly written) Bitcoin client will only use seed nodes once, the first time it starts up.
Because you don't rely on it except for bootstrapping: (properly written) Bitcoin clients keep a local peer list.
